importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The first dhow was boarded and drugs seized on this date, marking the start of the 48-hour operation.
The U.S. Central Command publicly congratulated the operation on this date, indicating international recognition and real-time global relevance.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 48-hour period during which two interception operations occurred, highlighting the intensity and coordination of the operation.

keyTakeAways: The Pakistani navy, operating under the Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces (CMF), intercepted two vessels in the Arabian Sea and seized narcotics valued at over $972 million.
The first dhow was seized on October 18, containing over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine (ICE) valued at $822.4 million.
The second dhow was seized less than 48 hours later, containing 350 kg of ICE worth $140 million and 50 kg of cocaine worth $10 million.
The intercepted vessels had no declared nationality and were identified as possibly originating from untraceable regions.
The operation was part of Combined Maritime Forces Task Force 150, a multi-national naval effort focused on combating maritime drug trafficking.
The U.S. Central Command publicly commended the operation, underscoring its global significance and the role of international cooperation in counter-narcotics efforts.
This seizure is described as one of the most successful in CMF history and highlights the effectiveness of multi-national maritime collaboration.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan Navy
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The naval force of Pakistan responsible for conducting the interception operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Pakistan Navy executed the actual boarding and seizure of the drug-laden vessels, making it central to the operation's execution.

namedEntities.name: Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces (CMF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A multinational naval coalition tasked with maritime security and counter-smuggling operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The CMF oversaw and coordinated the operation, emphasizing international cooperation in combating narcotics trafficking.

namedEntities.name: Combined Maritime Forces Task Force 150
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A specific naval task force under the CMF that conducted the 48-hour drug interception operation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It directly carried out the operations and was cited as achieving one of the most successful seizures in CMF history.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Central Command (CENTCOM)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. military command responsible for operations in the Middle East and Central Asia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It publicly congratulated the operation, reflecting global strategic interest in maritime drug interdiction efforts.

namedEntities.name: Yarmook
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The name of the Pakistani navy ship used in the boarding operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the vessel that conducted the actual boarding of the dhows, making it a key operational asset.

namedEntities.name: Crystal methamphetamine (ICE)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of synthetic drug seized in large quantities during the operation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The presence of high-value, illicit drugs underscores the severity and scale of the trafficking operation.

namedEntities.name: Dhow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A traditional sailing vessel used in the Arabian Sea, repurposed for illicit drug transport.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The vessels used were dhows, indicating the use of traditional, hard-to-detect maritime transport methods for smuggling.

namedEntities.name: October 18, 2025
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The date when the first dhow was intercepted and drugs seized.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This marks the beginning of the operation, with the seizure of over 2 tonnes of ICE.

namedEntities.name: October 21, 2025
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The date when the U.S. Central Command issued a public congratulation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It highlights the international recognition and strategic importance of the operation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Pakistan Navy, operating under the Saudi-led Combined Maritime Forces (CMF) Task Force 150, conducted a highly successful 48-hour operation in the Arabian Sea, intercepting two unregistered dhows and seizing narcotics valued at over $972 million. The first dhow, boarded on October 18, contained over 2 tonnes of crystal methamphetamine (ICE) worth $822.4 million, while the second dhow, intercepted less than 48 hours later, carried 350 kg of ICE valued at $140 million and 50 kg of cocaine valued at $10 million. The vessels had no declared nationality, suggesting possible illicit origins. The operation was praised by the U.S. Central Command as a major achievement in international maritime security and counter-narcotics efforts, demonstrating the effectiveness of multi-national naval cooperation in combating maritime drug trafficking.
title: Pakistan navy seizes drugs worth nearly $1bn in the Arabian Sea
